slides.title: Commodities
slides.subtitle: Pristine state
slides.text: Societies around the world have relied on nearby forests for food, fuel and medicine for thousands of years. Traditional practices like agroforestry, and small-scale and shifting agriculture had a reduced impact on the surrounding environment and generated socioeconomic benefits for local communities.

slides.title: Commodities
slides.subtitle: Drivers of change
slides.text: As demand for commodities grows, deforestation from industrial-scale agriculture, illegal harvesting of timber and mining increases. The inability to track where products come from and a lack of consequences for environmental outcomes make it difficult to curb the impacts of these industries.

slides.title: Commodities
slides.subtitle: Compromised state
slides.text: The unsustainable expansion of commodity production can permanently damage ecosystems, displace local communities, exacerbate climate change, and accelerate biodiversity loss.

slides.title: Commodities
slides.subtitle: Recovery state
slides.text: Protecting forest habitats is key to maintaining biodiversity. With better data on where tree cover loss in important biodiversity ares is happening, governments can make more informed decisions related to concessions and conservation projects and civil society can call attention to areas at risk.
